Award.AwardTitle: Visualization study of vortex-line dynamics in a magnetically levitated helium-4 superfluid drop
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Abstract

Quantum vortices, which are like little tornados governed by the laws of quantum mechanics, are important in understanding the behavior of systems such as superfluid helium, superconductors, liquid crystals, neutrons stars and perhaps even cosmic strings in the early universe. This project explores the behavior of quantum vortices in small (~1cm) droplets of superfluid liquid helium. Magnetic levitation, which is the same technique being explored for high speed trains and elevators that can move in all 3 dimensions, is used to float the droplet and eliminate the influence of the walls and the motion of the vortices is imaged using tracer molecules which fluoresce when illuminated with laser light. These studies will help us better understand the behavior of this strange form of quantum matter and will benefit studies of advanced materials such as superconductors and liquid crystals. This project will also train a new generation of scientists in technologically important fields such as low-temperature physics, fluid dynamics and advanced laser technologies. The research team plans to conduct demonstrations involving magnetic levitation and superfluid helium in various educational and outreach programs at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory to introduce these scientific concepts to the general public.

Technical Abstract
This project addresses intriguing fundamental problems relevant to the dynamics of quantized vortex lines. The objectives include a thorough investigation on how the appearance of vortices can affect the stability of a rotating superfluid drop and an in-depth study of the evolution of a vortex tangle in a wall-free environment. In superfluid helium-4, vortex lines can be directly visualized by imaging tracer particles trapped on the lines. However, producing tracers in helium at low temperatures and imaging the trapped tracers remains challenging, and the container walls can often affect the vortex-line motion. This project employs a levitated helium-4 drop as the working system, in which the vortices can be produced via fast evaporative cooling and controllable drop rotation. These vortices can be decorated with metastable He2 molecular tracers which can be imaged using a laser-induced fluorescence technique. The study of the vortex configuration in a rotating helium-4 drop helps explain the observed drop morphology and allows the derivation of the stability diagram of rotating superfluid drops. Since a levitated helium drop may serve as a model for other superfluid drop systems, such as neutron stars, the results obtained in this study may generate broad interest. Visualizing the evolution of a vortex tangle in a helium drop can facilitate the study of central questions in quantum turbulence research, such as the existence of polarized vortex bundles and the generation of Kelvin waves on vortices; these studies can directly advance our knowledge about the characteristics of quantum turbulence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Vortices can be easily generated in stirred fluids. For instance, one may observe vortices in smoke rings, whirlpools in the wake of a swimmer, or the winds surrounding a tornado. Vortices also exist in the so-called quantum fluids such as superfluid helium-4. Unlike in water or air where vortices eventually disappear due to viscous dissipation of the fluid, in a quantum fluid vortices cannot decay due to the lack of viscosity. Each vortex in a quantum fluid carries a fixed amount (or “quantized”) orbital angular momentum. The motion of quantized vortices is responsible for a wide range of phenomena, such as the initiation of dissipation in some superconductors, the appearance of glitches in neutron star rotation, and even the possible formation of cosmic strings in the early universe. A systematic study of vortex dynamics in quantum fluids, especially in the absence of affect from container walls, may benefit a wide range of physical science disciplines.

 

A powerful method to study vortex motion is via direct vortex imaging. In superfluid helium-4, a vortex line has a thickness of about 500,000 times smaller than that of a hair. Imaging vortices is therefore very challenging. The principle investigator’s (PI) team designed an experiment aiming to conquer this challenge by visualizing vortices in a magnetically levitated superfluid helium-4 drop using He2 molecular tracers. These tracers can be produced via ionizing helium atoms and can be imaged by laser-induced fluorescence. The major activities included: 1) restoring an  superconducting magnet cryostat obtained from collaborator Maris’ lab for levitating helium drops and isolating them from container walls? and 2) developing a technique to produce He2 molecular tracers in the drop for decorating and imaging the vortices. 

 

Significant progresses have been made in both activities. The magnet cryostat was stored in Maris’ lab for over 10 years without operation. It arrived in the PI’s lab with many leaks and no documentation about its internal structure. During the funding period, the PI’s group first developed a diagnostic method to map out the detailed structure of the cryostat, and then they conducted thorough leak checking and fixed all the leaks. A gas handling and pumping system was constructed for the operation and cooling down of the cryostat. In recent tests, the PI’s group successfully cooled the magnet cryostat to the desired superconducting state. However, the magnet coil may have cracks or defects developed over the years and it quenches frequently before the needed magnetic field strength is achieved for drop levitation. The PI’s group plans to seek instrument funds in the future to build a new superconducting coil to continue the effort.

 

To produce He2 molecular tracers in liquid helium in a controllable manner, the PI’s group came up with the idea of using strong laser beam to ionize the helium atoms. This work turns out to be remarkably fruitful. By focusing a femtosecond laser into helium, the PI’s group has successfully demonstrated the creation of He2 molecules. The team quickly realizes that this method not only allows for producing He2 molecular tracers but can also be used to measure the velocity field in helium. An extremely powerful molecular tagging velocimetry (MTV) technique was developed consequently. This MTV technique has been applied to study heat-induced counterflow in superfluid helium, a process that occurs naturally during drop cooling. Valuable experimental data were obtained, which  revealed a novel form of turbulence in counterflow and also resolved some long-lasting puzzles in the decay of counterflow turbulence. Relevant results have led to seven high quality papers.

 

These achievements in the funding period have important scientific and educational impacts. The experience gained by the team in designing and operating the levitation magnet is valuable in building new magnet infrastructures at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory (NHMFL). The MTV technique allows unambiguous quantitative velocity field measurement in cryogenic helium, which unlocks the full potential of helium in turbulence modeling and in cooling system applications. The laser-induced fluorescence based detection of He2 molecules can also be used to detect energetic particles, such as dark matter particles or ultracold neutrons, and it may also be useful for gamma ray imaging. These techniques are profitable for topics throughout particle physics research, as well as for practical applications such as radioactive material monitoring for US customs and border protection. The program has engaged both undergraduate and graduate students in the rapidly-expanding quantum fluid research field, where they have gained valuable experience in fluid dynamics, cryogenics, and advanced laser technologies. These skills are applicable to many STEM-related fields, giving these students the technical dexterity necessary to excel in today’s science- and technology-dominated job market. The team has also contributed in various educational and outreach programs at the NSF funded NHMFL for effectively promoting public awareness of quantum fluid research.
